papers.title: Climates of Terrestrial Exoplanets and Biosignatures
papers.abstract: Understanding the climates of terrestrial exoplanets and the detectability of biosignatures is an inherently interdisciplinary challenge, requiring the integration of insights from Solar System exploration, exoplanet observations and climate science. Building from Earth as the only known inhabited planet, NCCR PlanetS has developed models, tools and observational strategies to assess planetary environments far beyond direct reach. Between 2018 and 2025, PlanetS made major contributions across theory, modelling, instrumentation and mission preparation. On the modelling side, the Generic Planetary Climate Model enabled climate studies across a wide range of planetary regimes, from early Venus to temperate terrestrial exoplanets including Proxima b, incorporating advanced developments such as a dynamical slab ocean. In parallel, the THOR global climate model was developed to avoid Earth-centric assumptions and to stably simulate diverse atmospheric regimes. PlanetS has also advanced atmospheric retrieval techniques combining forward modelling, Bayesian inference and machine learning, applied to targets ranging from Solar System bodies to exoplanet phase curves and directly imaged spectra. These efforts have helped assess the scientific return of future missions, notably the Large Interferometer for Exoplanets (LIFE) and to define instrumental requirements for detecting Earth-like atmospheres and biosignatures. Within the Solar System, PlanetS contributed key technologies for biosignature detection, including ORIGIN and SenseLife, enabling in-situ and remote detection of organics, isotopic ratios and microstructures. Finally, PlanetS has played a major role in preparing the next generation of observatories, from JWST, VLT and ELT instruments to LIFE and the Habitable Worlds Observatory. Together, these contributions form an integrated framework advancing the search for life beyond Earth.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to identify signs of life on a distant world you can never visit‚Äîthat's the extraordinary challenge facing astronomers hunting for life beyond Earth. With thousands of planets discovered orbiting other stars, scientists are racing to develop the tools and techniques needed to study these alien worlds from trillions of miles away. This research represents a major leap forward in our ability to detect whether any of these distant planets might harbor life, potentially answering one of humanity's most profound questions: Are we alone in the universe?

**What They Did**

An international team of researchers spent seven years building a comprehensive toolkit for studying distant planets and searching for signs of life. Think of it like developing a detective kit for cosmic CSI work. They created computer models that can simulate weather and climate on alien worlds‚Äîimagine trying to predict the weather on a planet you've never seen, orbiting a completely different type of star. They also developed new ways to analyze the faint light that filters through distant planetary atmospheres, much like how you might identify ingredients in a soup by smelling the steam. Additionally, they built innovative instruments capable of detecting organic molecules and other potential signs of life, both for future space missions and ground-based telescopes.

**Key Findings**

The team successfully modeled climates for planets ranging from hellish Venus-like worlds to potentially habitable planets like Proxima b, our nearest exoplanet neighbor just 4.2 light-years away. Their atmospheric analysis techniques can now identify specific gases in alien atmospheres that might indicate biological processes. They've also contributed crucial technology for upcoming mega-telescopes and space missions, including instruments for the James Webb Space Telescope and the future Extremely Large Telescope, which will have a mirror nearly 130 feet across.

**Looking Forward**

This research lays the groundwork for the next generation of life-hunting missions. Within the next two decades, these tools and techniques could help identify the first confirmed signs of life on worlds beyond our solar system, marking a pivotal moment in human history.

papers.title: Exomoons and Exorings with the Habitable Worlds Observatory II: Finding Endor with Lunar Eclipses
papers.abstract: Giant planets in the habitable zone may host exomoons with conditions conducive to life. In this paper we describe a method by which the Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO) could detect such moons: broadband reflected-light lunar eclipses (e.g., the moon passing into the shadow of the planet). We find that an Earth-like moon orbiting a Jovian-size planet at 1au can outshine its host planet near 1 micron, producing frequent (days time-scale) lunar eclipses with depths of order 50%. We determine that single eclipse events out to ~12pc may be detectable for Earth-like moons around giant planets, down to 0.9R_‚äï. Detection of smaller moons, ~0.5R_‚äï (corresponding to about the size of Mars or Ganymede), may be possible, but would generally require multiple events for most systems. These several-hour events provide a clear pathway to detecting habitable moons with HWO, given sufficient stare-time on each system to detect lunar eclipses. The occurrence rate of habitable exomoons remains unconstrained, however, making the ultimate yield uncertain. HWO will be capable of placing the first meaningful constraints on the frequency of habitable exomoons around giant planets; if it is non-negligible, HWO could also search for life on these worlds, possibly with lunar eclipse spectroscopy.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Science fiction has long captivated us with the forest moon of Endor from Star Wars‚Äîa habitable world orbiting a giant planet. Now, real astronomers are figuring out how to find such places in our galaxy. If large planets like Jupiter can host Earth-sized moons in the "Goldilocks zone" where liquid water exists, we could dramatically expand the number of potentially life-supporting worlds in the universe. This matters because it means habitable real estate might be far more common than we think, giving life many more chances to emerge and thrive beyond our solar system.

**What They Did**

The researchers developed a clever new way to spot moons around distant planets using the upcoming Habitable Worlds Observatory, a powerful space telescope planned for the 2040s. Their method works like watching lunar eclipses in reverse‚Äîinstead of Earth's moon disappearing into our planet's shadow, they'd watch for the light signature when an exomoon passes into its giant planet's shadow. When this happens, the moon's reflected starlight suddenly vanishes, creating a distinctive dimming pattern that telescopes can detect. It's like noticing when someone turns off a flashlight in a dark room‚Äîthe sudden change in brightness gives away the presence of something that was there before.

**Key Findings**

The team discovered that Earth-sized moons orbiting Jupiter-like planets could actually outshine their host planets at certain wavelengths, making them surprisingly easy to spot. These lunar eclipses would happen frequently‚Äîevery few days‚Äîand cause dramatic 50% drops in brightness that last several hours. The telescope could detect moons as small as 90% of Earth's size around planets up to 39 light-years away, and possibly even Mars-sized moons with repeated observations.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides the first realistic roadmap for discovering habitable moons beyond our solar system. While we don't yet know how common such moons are, the Habitable Worlds Observatory could finally answer this fundamental question and potentially even analyze their atmospheres for signs of life.

papers.title: The RoPES project with HARPS and HARPS-N II. A third planet in the multi-planet system HD 176986
papers.abstract: Earth-like planets orbiting in the habitable zone of K- to G-type stars create an RV effect in amplitude of less than 1 and have orbital periods of hundreds of days. Only long-term RV surveys with sub-meter per second precision instruments can explore the outer regions of Sun-like stars and look for Earth-like planets and super-Earths. We present the analysis of the K-type star HD 176986. It has a brightness of V=8.45 mag and a distance from the Sun of d = 27.88 pc. This star hosts a known planetary system of two super-Earths. We joined historical datasets with new data collected in an ongoing blind search program. We took advantage of recently developed tools for RV extraction and stellar activity filtering. The analysis of activity indicators permits us to determine the period of the magnetic cycle of the star alongside its rotation period. We performed a joint analysis of RVs and activity indicators through multidimensional GPs to better constrain the activity model in RVs and avoid overfitting. We detected a new planet orbiting the star and retrieved the two known planets. HD 176986 b has an orbital period of 6.49164 (+0.00030/-0.00029) d and a minimum mass of 5.36 ¬± 0.44 M‚äï. HD 176986 c has an orbital period of P_c = 16.8124 ¬± 0.0015 d and a minimum mass of 9.75 (+0.65/-0.64) M‚äï. HD 176986 d has an orbital period of 61.376 (+0.051/-0.049) d and a minimum mass of 6.76 (+0.91/-0.92) M‚äï. From the analysis of activity indicators, we find evidence of a magnetic cycle with a period of 2432 (+64/-59) d, along with a rotation period of 36.05 (+0.67/-0.71) d. We discover a new planet in the multi-planet system orbiting the K-type star HD 176986. All the planets have minimum masses compatible with super-Earths or mini-Neptunes.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to spot a firefly circling a lighthouse from hundreds of miles away‚Äîthat's essentially what astronomers face when hunting for Earth-like planets around distant stars. This challenge becomes even more daunting when searching for planets that might harbor life, as these worlds orbit in the "Goldilocks zone" where water could exist as a liquid. This new research represents a major step forward in our ability to detect these elusive worlds, demonstrating that patient, long-term observations can reveal planetary systems remarkably similar to our own solar system's architecture.

**What They Did**

The research team spent years monitoring a star called HD 176986, located about 91 light-years from Earth, using ultra-precise instruments that can detect the tiny wobbles a star makes when planets orbit around it. Think of it like watching a dancer spin with invisible partners‚Äîyou can't see the partners directly, but their gravitational pull causes telltale movements in the dancer's motion. The team combined historical observations with new data, using advanced computer techniques to filter out the "noise" caused by the star's own magnetic activity and rotation, which can mask the subtle signals from orbiting planets.

**Key Findings**

The astronomers discovered a third planet in what was previously known to be a two-planet system. All three worlds are "super-Earths"‚Äîplanets larger than Earth but smaller than Neptune. The innermost planet completes an orbit every 6.5 days and has at least 5.4 times Earth's mass. The middle planet orbits every 16.8 days with 9.8 Earth masses, while the newly discovered outermost planet takes 61.4 days to orbit and weighs in at 6.8 Earth masses. They also determined that the host star rotates once every 36 days and experiences magnetic cycles lasting about 6.7 years.

**Looking Forward**

This discovery showcases how advanced detection methods can unveil complex planetary systems that were previously hidden. As these techniques improve, astronomers will be better equipped to find Earth-sized planets in habitable zones around sun-like stars, bringing us closer to answering whether worlds like ours‚Äîand potentially life itself‚Äîare common in the galaxy.

papers.title: Self-consistent N-body simulation of Planetesimal-Driven Migration. II. The effect of PDM on planet formation from a planetesimal disk
papers.abstract: According to the canonical planet formation theory, planets form "in-situ" within a planetesimal disk via runaway and oligarchic growth. This theory, however, cannot naturally account for the formation timescale of ice giants or the existence of diverse exoplanetary systems. Planetary migration is a key to resolving these problems. One well-known mechanism of planetary migration is planetesimal-driven migration (PDM), which can let planets undergo significant migration through gravitational scattering of planetesimals. In our previous paper (Jinno et al. 2024, PASJ, 76, 1309), we investigated the migration of a single planet through PDM, addressing previously unexplored aspects of both the gravitational interactions among planetesimals and the interactions with disk gas. Here we perform the first high-resolution simulations of planet formation from a large-scale planetesimal disk, incorporating planet-gas disk interactions, planet-planetesimal interactions, gravitational interactions among all planetesimals, and physical collisions between planetesimals to investigate the role of PDM in the planet formation process. Our results show that protoplanets undergo dynamic inward/outward migrations during the runaway growth stage via PDM. Moreover, orbital repulsion combined with PDM tends to make two groups of protoplanets, outer ones going outward and inner ones going inward. Such dynamic migration significantly influences the early stages of planetary formation. These findings provide a viable pathway for the formation of Earth-like planets and ice giants' cores. Furthermore, they suggest that a standard protoplanetary disk model can account for the planetary migration necessary to explain diverse exoplanetary systems without the need for additional hypotheses.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

For decades, astronomers have puzzled over how planets form and end up where they do. Our solar system has small, rocky planets close to the Sun and giant gas planets farther out‚Äîbut many alien solar systems look completely different, with massive planets hugging their stars or unusual arrangements we can't easily explain. This research tackles one of astronomy's biggest questions: how do planets move around during their birth, and why do we see such incredible diversity among planetary systems throughout the galaxy?

**What They Did**

The researchers created the most detailed computer simulation ever made of how planets form from cosmic debris. Think of it like modeling a cosmic construction site where billions of space rocks‚Äîcalled planetesimals‚Äîslowly clump together under gravity to build planets. Their virtual universe included all the key players: the gravitational pull between every piece of debris, collisions between rocks, the gas swirling around young stars, and most importantly, how growing planets can migrate by essentially playing gravitational pinball with the surrounding rubble. Previous studies had to simplify this process, but these scientists included all the messy, complex interactions happening simultaneously.

**Key Findings**

The simulations revealed that baby planets don't just grow quietly in place‚Äîthey're constantly on the move. As these "protoplanets" sweep up surrounding debris through gravitational interactions, they get pushed around like cosmic bumper cars. The researchers discovered that inner planets tend to spiral inward toward their star, while outer planets migrate outward. This dynamic shuffling happens early in planetary formation and creates two distinct groups of planets with very different destinies.

**Looking Forward**

This research offers a elegant solution to long-standing mysteries in planetary science. The migration process could explain how ice giants like Neptune formed quickly enough and why we see such bizarre exoplanetary arrangements. Most excitingly, it suggests that the standard model of planet formation can account for the wild diversity we observe without requiring exotic scenarios‚Äîthe universe's planetary systems might be more predictable than we thought.

papers.title: Stellar and orbital characterization of three low mass M dwarf binary stars with dynamical spectroscopy from the Habitable Zone Planet Finder
papers.abstract: Theoretical models of low-mass stars continue to be discrepant with observations when used to examine the mass-radius relationship and other physical parameters of individual stars. High-resolution spectroscopy that leads to dynamical measurements of binary stars can directly improve these models. We have been using the Habitable-zone Planet Finder spectrograph to monitor binary stars with M dwarf components. Here, we measure the orbital and stellar parameters for three such systems: LSPM J0515+5911, NLTT 43564, and NLTT 45468. Each system has dozens of spectra obtained over a baseline of several years. None of the systems appear to be eclipsing, so our ability to turn them into true benchmark binaries with purely dynamical measurements is limited. We use literature photometry to estimate each system's spectral energy distribution and utilize models in combination with detection limits of our spectroscopic measurements to probe characteristics of the companions. LSPM J0515+5911 is a double-lined spectroscopic binary with period of 126.948 ¬± 0.029 days and derived minimum masses, M_1^3i =0.058 ¬± 0.002 M_‚òâ and M_2^3i = 0.046 ¬± 0.001 M_‚òâ for the primary and secondary components, respectively. We solved NLTT 43564 with period of 1877 ¬± 24 days and NLTT 45468 with period of 9.686 ¬± 0.001 days as single lined systems, and modeled the primary masses to be M_1 = 0.32¬±0.02 M_‚òâ and M_1 = 0.35 (+0.02/-0.07) M_‚òâ, respectively.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

When astronomers search for planets beyond our solar system‚Äîcalled exoplanets‚Äîthey often look around small, dim stars called M dwarfs. These stars are much smaller and cooler than our Sun, but they're incredibly important because they make up about 75% of all stars in our galaxy. Many potentially habitable planets have been discovered orbiting these stellar neighbors. However, there's a problem: our computer models that predict how these stars should behave don't match what we actually observe when we study them in detail. It's like having a recipe that doesn't produce the cake you expect. To find and understand planets around these stars‚Äîespecially planets that might support life‚Äîscientists need to get their models right first.

**What They Did**

Researchers used a powerful instrument called the Habitable-zone Planet Finder, which can detect incredibly subtle changes in starlight, to study pairs of M dwarf stars orbiting each other (called binary stars). Think of it like using a super-sensitive microphone to hear two dancers' footsteps as they waltz‚Äîby listening carefully to the rhythm, you can figure out how heavy each dancer is and how they're moving. The team collected dozens of observations of three different star pairs over several years, measuring tiny shifts in the light that reveal how fast the stars are moving toward or away from us as they orbit each other.

**Key Findings**

The scientists successfully measured the orbital characteristics of all three binary systems. One pair, LSPM J0515+5911, completes an orbit every 127 days, with the stars weighing about 6% and 5% of our Sun's mass respectively‚Äîmaking them incredibly lightweight by stellar standards. Another pair, NLTT 43564, takes over five years to complete one orbit, while the third system, NLTT 45468, whips around in less than 10 days. These measurements provide crucial "ground truth" data that can help correct theoretical models of how small stars work.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides the precise stellar measurements needed to improve computer models of M dwarf stars. Better models mean more accurate characterizations of planets orbiting these stars, bringing us closer to identifying worlds that might harbor life. As our stellar understanding improves, so does our ability to determine which exoplanets have the right conditions for habitability.

papers.title: Orbital stability of compact three-planet systems III. The role of three-body resonances
papers.abstract: Observational surveys show that at least ~ 30% of short-period multiplanetary systems host tightly packed planets, some of which are locked in stable chains of mean-motion resonances. Despite recent progress, the dynamical stability of these systems remains only partially understood. Numerical simulations have established a general exponential increase in system lifetime with orbital separation, with mean-motion resonances playing a key role in regulating stability. Tightly packed three-planet systems exhibit a distinctive behavior not seen in higher-multiplicity systems: a small yet significant region of phase space is anomalously stable. This study investigates the dynamics of extremely compact three-planet systems, focusing on anomalously long-lived configurations and their connection to resonant chains observed in exoplanetary systems. We perform numerical integrations of coplanar, initially circular, equal-mass three-planet systems over stellar-lifetime timescales and at high resolution in orbital separation, and interpret the results in the context of recent analytical work. We identify regions of phase space hosting anomalously stable orbits, including systems surviving multiple orders of magnitude longer than predicted by the exponential trend. We demonstrate a clear link between stability and isolated three-body mean-motion resonances, showing that extremely compact systems can remain stable when captured into a small subset of isolated zeroth-order resonances. Stability further depends on the initial orbital longitudes and on the interplay between the three-body and two-body resonance networks.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine three planets orbiting so close to each other that they should, by all rights, crash into one another or get flung out of their solar system entirely. Yet astronomers have discovered that roughly 30% of planetary systems beyond our solar system contain exactly these kinds of tightly packed worlds‚Äîand somehow, they've remained stable for billions of years. Understanding how these cosmic juggling acts work helps us grasp the incredible diversity of planetary systems in our galaxy and sheds light on how planets form and evolve. These findings also help astronomers predict which newly discovered exoplanets might have stayed stable long enough to potentially harbor life.

**What They Did**

The researchers created detailed computer simulations of three-planet systems, like building virtual solar systems on a computer. They started with three planets of equal mass orbiting in perfect circles around a star, then placed them at various distances from each other‚Äîsome farther apart, others packed incredibly tightly together. Think of it like testing different arrangements of spinning tops on a table to see which ones keep spinning without knocking each other over. The scientists then let these virtual planets orbit for timescales equivalent to the entire lifetime of a star‚Äîbillions of years‚Äîto see which arrangements would survive and which would fall apart.

**Key Findings**

The study revealed a surprising discovery: some extremely tightly packed three-planet systems can survive thousands or even millions of times longer than scientists expected. This happens when the planets get locked into special gravitational dance patterns called "resonances"‚Äîimagine three dancers moving in perfect synchronization so they never collide. Unlike larger planetary systems with more planets, three-planet systems have unique stable zones that don't exist when more worlds are involved. The exact starting positions of the planets also matter tremendously, with some arrangements leading to billion-year stability while others cause rapid chaos.

**Looking Forward**

These results could revolutionize how astronomers search for and study compact planetary systems. By understanding which configurations remain stable over cosmic timescales, scientists can better predict where to look for potentially habitable worlds and interpret observations of real exoplanet systems. This research also provides crucial insights into planetary system architecture, helping explain why certain arrangements of planets are common in nature while others are rare.

papers.title: Extreme winds on the emerging dayside of an ultrahot Jupiter
papers.abstract: High-resolution spectroscopy provides a unique opportunity to directly probe atmospheric dynamics by resolving Doppler shifts of planetary signal as a function of orbital phases. Using the optical spectrometer Keck Planet Finder (KPF), we carry out a pilot study on high-resolution phase curve spectra of the ultra-hot Jupiter KELT-9 b. We spectrally and temporally resolve its dayside emission from post-transit to pre-eclipse (orbital phase phi = 0.1 - 0.45). The signal strength and width increase with orbital phases as the dayside rotates into view. The net Doppler shift varies progressively from -13.4 +/- 0.6 to -0.4 +/- 1.0 km/s, the extent of which exceeds its rotation velocity of 6.4 +/- 0.1 km/s, providing unambiguous evidence of atmospheric winds. We devise a retrieval framework to fit the full time-series spectra, accounting for the variation of line profiles due to the rotation and winds. We retrieve a supersonic day-to-night wind speed up to 11.7 +/- 0.6 km/s on the emerging dayside, representing the most extreme atmospheric winds in hot Jupiters to date. Comparison to 3D circulation models reveals a weak atmospheric drag, consistent with relatively efficient heat recirculation as also supported by space-based phase curve measurements. Additionally, we retrieve the dayside chemistry (including Fe i, Fe ii, Ti i, Ti ii, Ca i, Ca ii, Mg i, and Si i) and temperature structure, and place constraints on the nightside thermal profile. Our high-resolution phase curve spectra and the measured supersonic winds provide excellent benchmarks for extreme physics in circulation models, demonstrating the power of this technique in understanding climates of hot Jupiters.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to understand Earth's climate by only studying one spot at one time‚Äîyou'd miss hurricanes, jet streams, and all the dynamic weather that shapes our world. Until recently, scientists studying planets beyond our solar system faced a similar challenge. This groundbreaking research changes that by giving us the first detailed look at extreme weather patterns on an alien world called KELT-9 b, one of the hottest planets ever discovered. Understanding how atmospheres behave on these exotic worlds doesn't just satisfy our curiosity‚Äîit helps us better comprehend how planetary climates work in general, including our own.

**What They Did**

The researchers used a powerful new instrument called the Keck Planet Finder, essentially a ultra-sensitive light detector that can pick up incredibly subtle changes in starlight. As KELT-9 b orbits its star, different parts of the planet rotate into view, like watching someone slowly turn around. The team tracked how light from different atmospheric gases shifted in color due to the planet's rotation and wind movement‚Äîsimilar to how an ambulance siren changes pitch as it moves toward or away from you. By monitoring these tiny shifts over several hours, they could map the planet's atmospheric motion in unprecedented detail.

**Key Findings**

The winds on KELT-9 b are absolutely ferocious‚Äîreaching speeds of nearly 12 kilometers per second, or about 26,000 miles per hour. To put that in perspective, that's roughly 35 times faster than the strongest hurricane winds on Earth and actually faster than the speed of sound in the planet's atmosphere. These supersonic winds race from the planet's scorching dayside (which faces its star) toward the cooler nightside. The researchers also identified the chemical fingerprints of various metals vaporized in the extreme heat, including iron, titanium, and calcium floating as gases in the atmosphere.

**Looking Forward**

This research opens a new era of exoplanet meteorology, proving we can now study alien weather patterns in real-time. These extreme measurements will help scientists refine computer models that predict how heat and chemicals move through planetary atmospheres, improving our understanding of potentially habitable worlds and the diverse climates that exist throughout our galaxy.

papers.title: The CO snow line favours strong clumping by the streaming instability in protoplanetary discs with porous grains
papers.abstract: Context: The radial drift and fragmentation of small dust grains in protoplanetary discs impedes their growth past centimetre sizes. Several mechanisms have been proposed to overcome these planet formation barriers, such as dust porosity or the streaming instability (SI), which is today regarded as the most promising mechanism to form planetesimals. Aims: Here, we examine whether the conditions for the SI to lead to strong clumping, the first step in planetesimal formation, are realised in protoplanetary discs containing porous grains. Methods: We used results from previous simulations of the evolution of porous grains subjected to growth, fragmentation, compaction and bouncing in protoplanetary discs. In the ensuing disc structures, we determined the regions where the dust-to-gas ratio exceeds the critical value for strong clumping found in simulations of the SI including external turbulence. Results: We find that the conditions for strong clumping are met within the first hundred thousand years in large regions of protoplanetary discs containing porous grains, provided that the CO snow line is taken into account. If the CO snow line is neglected, the conditions are met only very close to the inner disc edge early on, or over large areas well after 200,000 yr.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Understanding how planets form is one of astronomy's greatest puzzles‚Äîand it directly helps us understand how our own solar system, including Earth, came to exist. For decades, scientists have struggled to explain a major roadblock in planet formation: how tiny dust grains in space manage to stick together and grow into the building blocks of planets. It's like trying to build a sandcastle where the sand keeps blowing away before you can pack it together. This research tackles that fundamental question by studying the conditions that allow dust to clump together in the swirling discs of gas and dust that surround young stars.

**What They Did**

The researchers used computer simulations to model what happens inside protoplanetary discs‚Äîthe spinning pancakes of material around newborn stars where planets eventually form. They focused on "porous grains," which are fluffy dust particles with lots of empty space inside them, like cosmic cotton balls. The team tracked how these particles grow, break apart, get compressed, and bounce off each other over time. They then identified regions where dust becomes concentrated enough to trigger something called the "streaming instability"‚Äîa process that causes dust to spontaneously clump together into dense patches, like cream separating in coffee.

**Key Findings**

The breakthrough discovery involves the "CO snow line"‚Äîthe invisible boundary in space where carbon monoxide gas freezes into ice, similar to how water vapor becomes snow on a cold day. When the researchers included this boundary in their models, they found that conditions favorable for dust clumping occurred within the first 100,000 years across large regions of the disc. Without considering this snow line, dust only clumped near the very center early on, or required more than 200,000 years to clump elsewhere.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides a crucial piece of the planet formation puzzle, showing how the streaming instability can work much more efficiently than previously thought when realistic dust properties are considered. It suggests that planetesimal formation‚Äîthe first major step toward building planets‚Äîcan happen relatively quickly and in many locations within protoplanetary discs, making planetary systems like ours more likely to form.

papers.title: Spatial distribution of organics in the Horsehead nebula: signposts of chemistry driven by atomic carbon
papers.abstract: (Abridged) Complex organic molecules (COMs) are considered essential precursors to prebiotic species. While COMs were once expected to be efficiently destroyed under UV-irradiated conditions, detections in photodissociation regions (PDRs) have challenged this view. However, the mechanisms by which UV radiation contributes to their formation are still uncertain. Here, we present moderately resolved maps of simple and complex organic molecules at the UV-illuminated edge of the Horsehead nebula, obtained by combining ALMA and IRAM 30m single-dish observations at ~ 15^() resolution. We analyze the spatial distribution of species such as C^(17)O, CH_2CO, CH_3CHO, HNCO, CH_3CN, and HC_3N. By incorporating previous C^(17)O and C^(18)O single-dish data as well as PdBI maps of H_2CO and CH_3OH, we derive profiles of gas density, temperature, thermal pressure, and column densities of the organic species as a function of distance from the UV source. Our results show that most organic species-particularly H_2CO, CH_2CO, CH_3CHO, HNCO, and CH_3CN-exhibit enhanced column densities at the UV-illuminated edge compared to cloud interiors, possibly indicating efficient dust-grain surface chemistry driven by the diffusion of atomic C and radicals produced via photodissociation of CO and CH_3OH, as supported by recent laboratory experiments. The exceptions, HC_3N and CH_3OH, can be attributed to inefficient formation on dust grains and ineffective non-thermal desorption into the gas phase, respectively. Additionally, contributions from gas-phase hydrocarbon photochemistry-possibly seeded by grain-surface products-cannot be ruled out. Further chemical modeling is needed to confirm the efficiency of these pathways for the studied species, which could have important implications for other cold, UV-irradiated environments such as protoplanetary disks.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Life as we know it depends on complex organic molecules‚Äîthe carbon-based building blocks that eventually form proteins, DNA, and other essential components of living organisms. For decades, scientists have been searching for these molecular precursors in space to understand how the ingredients for life might spread throughout the universe and seed new worlds. This research tackles a fundamental puzzle: how do these delicate organic molecules survive and even thrive in the harsh, radiation-soaked regions of space where ultraviolet light should theoretically destroy them? The answer could reshape our understanding of how life's building blocks form and persist in the cosmos, including around other stars where planets might be forming.

**What They Did**

The research team used powerful radio telescopes‚Äîincluding the Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile‚Äîto create detailed maps of the famous Horsehead Nebula. Think of it like using a specialized camera that can detect the "fingerprints" of different molecules floating in space. They focused on the nebula's edge, where intense ultraviolet radiation from nearby hot stars creates conditions similar to a cosmic chemistry lab. By measuring various organic molecules at different distances from the radiation source, they could track how these chemicals behave under increasingly harsh conditions‚Äîlike studying how ingredients in a recipe change as you move closer to a heat source.

**Key Findings**

Surprisingly, most organic molecules didn't just survive the ultraviolet bombardment‚Äîthey actually became more abundant near the radiation source. Molecules like formaldehyde and acetaldehyde showed enhanced concentrations at the nebula's illuminated edge compared to its protected interior. The researchers discovered this happens because the radiation breaks apart simpler molecules like carbon monoxide, creating reactive atomic carbon that then combines with other elements on the surfaces of tiny dust grains to build more complex organic compounds.

**Looking Forward**

These findings suggest that planets forming around young, energetic stars‚Äîrather than being sterilized by radiation‚Äîmight actually receive more organic building blocks than previously thought. This research could help scientists identify which exoplanets are most likely to develop the chemistry necessary for life, expanding our search for habitable worlds beyond our solar system.
